t: Song of Solomon 1
Solomon’s*p Song of Songs.
She
Let*pn him kiss me with the kisses of his mouth— for*ld your love is more delightful than wine.
Pleasing*ln is the fragrance of your perfumes; your*ld name is like perfume poured out. No*ld wonder the young women love you!
Take*ln me away with you—let us hurry! Let*ld the king bring me into his chambers.
Friends
We*pn rejoice and delight in you; we*ld will praise your love more than wine.
She
How*pn right they are to adore you!
Dark*pn am I, yet lovely, daughters*ld of Jerusalem, dark*ln like the tents of Kedar, like*ld the tent curtains of Solomon.
Do*ln not stare at me because I am dark, because*ld I am darkened by the sun. My*ln mother’s sons were angry with me and*ld made me take care of the vineyards; my*ld own vineyard I had to neglect.
Tell*ln me, you whom I love, where*ld you graze your flock and*ld where you rest your sheep at midday. Why*ln should I be like a veiled woman beside*ld the flocks of your friends?
Friends
If*pn you do not know, most beautiful of women, follow*ld the tracks of the sheep and*ln graze your young goats by*ld the tents of the shepherds.
He
I*pn liken you, my darling, to a mare among*ld Pharaoh’s chariot horses.
Your*ln cheeks are beautiful with earrings, your*ld neck with strings of jewels.
We*ln will make you earrings of gold, studded*ld with silver.
She
While*pn the king was at his table, my*ld perfume spread its fragrance.
My*ln beloved is to me a sachet of myrrh resting*ld between my breasts.
My*ln beloved is to me a cluster of henna blossoms from*ld the vineyards of En Gedi.
He
How*pn beautiful you are, my darling! Oh,*ld how beautiful! Your*ld eyes are doves.
She
How*pn handsome you are, my beloved! Oh,*ld how charming! And*ld our bed is verdant.
He
The*pn beams of our house are cedars; our*ld rafters are firs.
Song of Solomon 2
She
I*pn am a rose of Sharon, a*ld lily of the valleys.
He
Like*pn a lily among thorns is*ld my darling among the young women.
She
Like*pn an apple tree among the trees of the forest is*ld my beloved among the young men. I*ln delight to sit in his shade, and*ld his fruit is sweet to my taste.
Let*ln him lead me to the banquet hall, and*ld let his banner over me be love.
Strengthen*ln me with raisins, refresh*ld me with apples, for*ld I am faint with love.
His*ln left arm is under my head, and*ld his right arm embraces me.
Daughters*ln of Jerusalem, I charge you by*ld the gazelles and by the does of the field: Do*ln not arouse or awaken love until*ld it so desires.
Listen!*pn My beloved! Look!*ld Here he comes, leaping*ln across the mountains, bounding*ld over the hills.
My*ln beloved is like a gazelle or a young stag. Look!*ld There he stands behind our wall, gazing*ln through the windows, peering*ld through the lattice.
My*ln beloved spoke and said to me, “Arise,*ld my darling, my*ld beautiful one, come with me.
See!*ln The winter is past; the*ld rains are over and gone.
Flowers*ln appear on the earth; the*ld season of singing has come, the*ln cooing of doves is*ld heard in our land.
The*ln fig tree forms its early fruit; the*ld blossoming vines spread their fragrance. Arise,*ln come, my darling; my*ld beautiful one, come with me.”
He
My*pn dove in the clefts of the rock, in*ld the hiding places on the mountainside, show*ln me your face, let*ld me hear your voice; for*ln your voice is sweet, and*ld your face is lovely.
Catch*ln for us the foxes, the*ld little foxes that*ln ruin the vineyards, our*ld vineyards that are in bloom.
She
My*pn beloved is mine and I am his; he*ld browses among the lilies.
Until*ln the day breaks and*ld the shadows flee, turn,*ln my beloved, and*ld be like a gazelle or*ln like a young stag on*ld the rugged hills.
Song of Solomon 3
All*pn night long on my bed I*ld looked for the one my heart loves; I*ld looked for him but did not find him.
I*ln will get up now and go about the city, through*ld its streets and squares; I*ln will search for the one my heart loves. So*ld I looked for him but did not find him.
The*ln watchmen found me as*ld they made their rounds in the city. “Have*ld you seen the one my heart loves?”

Scarcely*ln had I passed them when*ld I found the one my heart loves. I*ln held him and would not let him go till*ld I had brought him to my mother’s house, to*ld the room of the one who conceived me.
Daughters*ln of Jerusalem, I charge you by*ld the gazelles and by the does of the field: Do*ln not arouse or awaken love until*ld it so desires.
Who*pn is this coming up from the wilderness like*ld a column of smoke, perfumed*ln with myrrh and incense made*ld from all the spices of the merchant?
Look!*ln It is Solomon’s carriage, escorted*ld by sixty warriors, the*ld noblest of Israel,
all*ln of them wearing the sword, all*ld experienced in battle, each*ln with his sword at his side, prepared*ld for the terrors of the night.
King*ln Solomon made for himself the carriage; he*ld made it of wood from Lebanon.
Its*ln posts he made of silver, its*ld base of gold. Its*ln seat was upholstered with purple, its*ld interior inlaid with love. Daughters*ln of Jerusalem,
come out, and*ld look, you daughters of Zion. Look*ln on King Solomon wearing a crown, the*ld crown with which his mother crowned him on*ln the day of his wedding, the*ld day his heart rejoiced.
Song of Solomon 4
He
How*pn beautiful you are, my darling! Oh,*ld how beautiful! Your*ld eyes behind your veil are doves. Your*ln hair is like a flock of goats descending*ld from the hills of Gilead.
Your*ln teeth are like a flock of sheep just shorn, coming*ld up from the washing. Each*ln has its twin; not*ld one of them is alone.
Your*ln lips are like a scarlet ribbon; your*ld mouth is lovely. Your*ln temples behind your veil are*ld like the halves of a pomegranate.
Your*ln neck is like the tower of David, built*ld with courses of stone; on*ln it hang a thousand shields, all*ld of them shields of warriors.
Your*ln breasts are like two fawns, like*ld twin fawns of a gazelle that*ld browse among the lilies.
Until*ln the day breaks and*ld the shadows flee, I*ln will go to the mountain of myrrh and*ld to the hill of incense.
You*ln are altogether beautiful, my darling; there*ld is no flaw in you.

Come*pn with me from Lebanon, my bride, come*ld with me from Lebanon. Descend*ln from the crest of Amana, from*ld the top of Senir, the summit of Hermon, from*ln the lions’ dens and*ld the mountain haunts of leopards.
You*ln have stolen my heart, my sister, my bride; you*ld have stolen my heart with*ln one glance of your eyes, with*ld one jewel of your necklace.
How*ln delightful is your love, my sister, my bride! How*ld much more pleasing is your love than wine, and*ln the fragrance of your perfume more*ld than any spice!
Your*ln lips drop sweetness as the honeycomb, my bride; milk*ld and honey are under your tongue. The*ln fragrance of your garments is*ld like the fragrance of Lebanon.
You*ln are a garden locked up, my sister, my bride; you*ld are a spring enclosed, a sealed fountain.
Your*ln plants are an orchard of pomegranates with*ld choice fruits, with*ld henna and nard,
nard*ld and saffron, calamus*ld and cinnamon, with*ld every kind of incense tree, with*ld myrrh and aloes and*ld all the finest spices.
You*ln are a garden fountain, a*ld well of flowing water streaming*ld down from Lebanon.
She
Awake,*pn north wind, and*ld come, south wind! Blow*ln on my garden, that*ld its fragrance may spread everywhere. Let*ln my beloved come into his garden and*ld taste its choice fruits.
Song of Solomon 5
He
I*pn have come into my garden, my sister, my bride; I*ld have gathered my myrrh with my spice. I*ln have eaten my honeycomb and my honey; I*ld have drunk my wine and my milk.
Friends
Eat,*pn friends, and drink; drink*ld your fill of love.
She

I*pn slept but my heart was awake. Listen!*ld My beloved is knocking: “Open*ln to me, my sister, my darling, my*ld dove, my flawless one. My*ln head is drenched with dew, my*ld hair with the dampness of the night.”
I*ln have taken off my robe— must*ld I put it on again? I*ln have washed my feet— must*ld I soil them again?
My*ln beloved thrust his hand through the latch-opening; my*ld heart began to pound for him.
I*ln arose to open for my beloved, and*ld my hands dripped with myrrh, my*ln fingers with flowing myrrh, on*ld the handles of the bolt.
I*ln opened for my beloved, but*ld my beloved had left; he was gone. My*ld heart sank at his departure. I*ln looked for him but did not find him. I*ld called him but he did not answer.
The*ln watchmen found me as*ld they made their rounds in the city. They*ln beat me, they bruised me; they*ld took away my cloak, those*ld watchmen of the walls!
Daughters*ln of Jerusalem, I charge you— if*ld you find my beloved, what*ln will you tell him? Tell*ld him I am faint with love.
Friends
How*pn is your beloved better than others, most*ld beautiful of women? How*ln is your beloved better than others, that*ld you so charge us?
She
My*pn beloved is radiant and ruddy, outstanding*ld among ten thousand.
His*ln head is purest gold; his*ld hair is wavy and*ld black as a raven.
His*ln eyes are like doves by*ld the water streams, washed*ln in milk, mounted*ld like jewels.
His*ln cheeks are like beds of spice yielding*ld perfume. His*ln lips are like lilies dripping*ld with myrrh.
His*ln arms are rods of gold set*ld with topaz. His*ln body is like polished ivory decorated*ld with lapis lazuli.
His*ln legs are pillars of marble set*ld on bases of pure gold. His*ln appearance is like Lebanon, choice*ld as its cedars.
His*ln mouth is sweetness itself; he*ld is altogether lovely. This*ln is my beloved, this is my friend, daughters*ld of Jerusalem.
Song of Solomon 6
Friends
Where*pn has your beloved gone, most*ld beautiful of women? Which*ln way did your beloved turn, that*ld we may look for him with you?
She
My*pn beloved has gone down to his garden, to*ld the beds of spices, to*ln browse in the gardens and*ld to gather lilies.
I*ln am my beloved’s and my beloved is mine; he*ld browses among the lilies.
He
You*pn are as beautiful as Tirzah, my darling, as*ld lovely as Jerusalem, as*ld majestic as troops with banners.
Turn*ln your eyes from me; they*ld overwhelm me. Your*ln hair is like a flock of goats descending*ld from Gilead.
Your*ln teeth are like a flock of sheep coming*ld up from the washing. Each*ln has its twin, not*ld one of them is missing.
Your*ln temples behind your veil are*ld like the halves of a pomegranate.
Sixty*ln queens there may be, and*ld eighty concubines, and*ld virgins beyond number;

but*ln my dove, my perfect one, is unique, the*ld only daughter of her mother, the*ld favorite of the one who bore her. The*ln young women saw her and called her blessed; the*ld queens and concubines praised her.
Friends
Who*pn is this that appears like the dawn, fair*ld as the moon, bright as the sun, majestic*ld as the stars in procession?
He
I*pn went down to the grove of nut trees to*ld look at the new growth in the valley, to*ln see if the vines had budded or*ld the pomegranates were in bloom.
Before*ln I realized it, my*ld desire set me among the royal chariots of my people.
Friends
Come*pn back, come back, O Shulammite; come*ld back, come back, that we may gaze on you!
He
Why*pn would you gaze on the Shulammite as*ld on the dance of Mahanaim?
Song of Solomon 7
How*pn beautiful your sandaled feet, O*ld prince’s daughter! Your*ln graceful legs are like jewels, the*ld work of an artist’s hands.
Your*ln navel is a rounded goblet that*ld never lacks blended wine. Your*ln waist is a mound of wheat encircled*ld by lilies.
Your*ln breasts are like two fawns, like*ld twin fawns of a gazelle.
Your*ln neck is like an ivory tower. Your*ln eyes are the pools of Heshbon by*ld the gate of Bath Rabbim. Your*ln nose is like the tower of Lebanon looking*ld toward Damascus.
Your*ln head crowns you like Mount Carmel. Your*ld hair is like royal tapestry; the*ld king is held captive by its tresses.
How*ln beautiful you are and how pleasing, my*ld love, with your delights!
Your*ln stature is like that of the palm, and*ld your breasts like clusters of fruit.
I*ln said, “I will climb the palm tree; I*ld will take hold of its fruit.” May*ln your breasts be like clusters of grapes on the vine, the*ld fragrance of your breath like apples,
and*ld your mouth like the best wine.
She
May*pn the wine go straight to my beloved, flowing*ld gently over lips and teeth.
I*ln belong to my beloved, and*ld his desire is for me.
Come,*ln my beloved, let us go to the countryside, let*ld us spend the night in the villages.
Let*ln us go early to the vineyards to*ld see if the vines have budded, if*ln their blossoms have opened, and*ld if the pomegranates are in bloom— there*ld I will give you my love.
The*ln mandrakes send out their fragrance, and*ld at our door is every delicacy, both*ln new and old, that*ld I have stored up for you, my beloved.
Song of Solomon 8
If*pn only you were to me like a brother, who*ld was nursed at my mother’s breasts! Then,*ln if I found you outside, I*ld would kiss you, and*ld no one would despise me.
I*ln would lead you and*ld bring you to my mother’s house— she*ld who has taught me. I*ln would give you spiced wine to drink, the*ld nectar of my pomegranates.
His*ln left arm is under my head and*ld his right arm embraces me.
Daughters*ln of Jerusalem, I charge you: Do*ld not arouse or awaken love until*ld it so desires.
Friends
Who*pn is this coming up from the wilderness leaning*ld on her beloved?
She
Under*pn the apple tree I roused you; there*ld your mother conceived you, there*ld she who was in labor gave you birth.
Place*ln me like a seal over your heart, like*ld a seal on your arm; for*ln love is as strong as death, its*ld jealousy unyielding as the grave. It*ln burns like blazing fire, like*ld a mighty flame.
Many*ln waters cannot quench love; rivers*ld cannot sweep it away. If*ln one were to give all*ld the wealth of one’s house for love, it*ld would be utterly scorned.
Friends
We*pn have a little sister, and*ld her breasts are not yet grown. What*ln shall we do for our sister on*ld the day she is spoken for?
If*ln she is a wall, we*ld will build towers of silver on her. If*ln she is a door, we*ld will enclose her with panels of cedar.
She
I*pn am a wall, and*ld my breasts are like towers. Thus*ln I have become in his eyes like*ld one bringing contentment.
Solomon*ln had a vineyard in Baal Hamon; he*ld let out his vineyard to tenants. Each*ln was to bring for its fruit a*ld thousand shekels of silver.
But*ln my own vineyard is mine to give; the*ld thousand shekels are for you, Solomon, and*ld two hundred are for those who tend its fruit.
He
You*pn who dwell in the gardens with*ld friends in attendance, let*ld me hear your voice!
She
Come*pn away, my beloved, and*ld be like a gazelle or*ln like a young stag on*ld the spice-laden mountains.
